item.title: Connecticut 87, South Carolina 62: UConn Sends Message With a Rout of No. 1 South Carolina
item.description: In a showdown, No. 2 Connecticut handed the top-ranked Gamecocks their first loss of the season.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW DAS
item.media:description: Moriah Jefferson, defending South Carolina’s Khadijah Sessions, had 16 points in No. 2 Connecticut’s victory.

item.title: Malaysian Court Upholds Opposition Leader’s Sodomy Conviction
item.description: The decision Tuesday on Anwar Ibrahim’s final appeal was likely to remove him as the linchpin of a fractious but ascendant opposition.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim gestures while addressing his supporters at a gathering in Kuala Lumpur on Monday night.

item.title: Dozens Expected to Be Charged in Construction Permit Plot
item.description: New York City building inspectors, property owners and private contractors are expected to be arrested on Tuesday in a scheme to speed up approval of construction projects.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: In de Blasio’s Budget Plan, an Emphasis on Public Safety and Social Programs
item.description: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initial plan for the 2016 fiscal year relies on prosperity to support a budget that includes no tax increases and virtually no service cuts.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM and NIKITA STEWART
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio presented his initial budget plan for the 2016 fiscal year on Monday.

item.title: Illinois Governor Acts to Curb Power of Public Sector Unions
item.description: Gov. Bruce Rauner, a Republican, announced on Monday an executive order that would ban unions from requiring all state workers to pay the equivalent of dues.
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
item.dc:creator: By MONICA DAVEY and MITCH SMITH
item.media:description: Gov. Bruce Rauner speaking to students at the University of Chicago last month.

item.title: Ed Sabol, NFL Films Founder, Dies at 98
item.description: Mr. Sabol and his son marshaled exquisite photography, rhapsodic music and poetry to elevate pro football to the realm of myth.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Ed Sabol, in an undated photo, began his company from a hobby pursued through a wedding gift.

item.title: For Alabama Chief Justice, Soldiering in Name of God Is Nothing New
item.description: Roy Moore was firm in his position that the federal judiciary had seriously overreached in its effort to impose same-sex marriage in Alabama.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD FAUSSET
item.media:credit: Jeff Haller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Justice Roy Moore of Alabama, who ordered defiance of a same-sex marriage ruling, once fought to keep a Ten Commandments marker in a judicial building.

item.title: Gay Marriage in Alabama Begins, but Only in Parts
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court refused to stay a ruling that overturned Alabama’s ban on gay marriage, and many probate judges issued licenses in defiance of an order from the state’s chief justice.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ALAN BLINDER and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.media:description: Same-sex couples waited for the Jefferson County courthouse doors to open on Monday in Birmingham.

item.title: Obama Awaits Outcome of Ukraine Peace Talks Before Deciding on Arms
item.description: Appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, President Obama expressed hope for a diplomatic solution in Ukraine but said the United States would consider sending weapons if talks failed.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Obama and Netanyahu Clash From Afar Over Israeli’s Planned Speech
item.description: A dispute over politics and protocol dramatized a deepening rift between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over a potential nuclear deal with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Supreme Court Undercuts Alabama Chief Justice’s Argument to Delay Same-Sex Marriages
item.description: Legal experts said Alabama’s clash of federal and state authority on the issue would almost surely end with state officials honoring the decision by a Federal District Court judge allowing the unions.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM

item.title: China Hits Qualcomm With Fine
item.description: In addition to the fine, which was a record for China, the Qualcomm, the chip maker, agreed to sharply reduce the royalties it charges Chinese smartphone makers.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR and QUENTIN HARDY
item.media:description: Paul E. Jacobs, chief executive of Qualcomm, displays a Snapdragon 800 series chip.

item.title: On Baseball: With New Flair, Padres Move to Sign Shields, a Workhorse
item.description: James Shields, a top starter, was said to have agreed to a four-year, $75 million deal with the Padres, who are quickly shedding their bland reputation.
item.dc:creator: By TYLER KEPNER
item.media:description: James Shields has twice helped low-budget teams reach the World Series, and he has pitched at least 200 innings for eight consecutive seasons.

item.title: Amami Oshima Journal: Old Ways Prove Hard to Shed, Even as Crisis Hits Kimono Trade
item.description: The island of Amami Oshima has fallen harder than most of Japan’s famous kimono production centers.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washing silk in a river. Artisans on Amami Oshima uses the island’s iron-rich mud to turn silk a rich shade of chocolate brown.

item.title: Towers of Secrecy: Amid Complaints in India, a Real Estate Deal in Manhattan
item.description: As reports of unfinished homes mounted against Kabul Chawla, a New Delhi builder, an opaque corporate entity bought a $19 million condo at the Time Warner Center.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHANIE SAUL and LOUISE STORY
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neeraj Jagga bought this apartment in a 4,000-unit complex near New Delhi but said construction had barely progressed in three years. The developer, Kabul Chawla, has been the subject of numerous consumer complaints.

item.title: ‘American Sniper’ Trial Sets Town on Edge
item.description: Chris Kyle’s celebrity hangs over the trial and the town, larger in death than it was in life.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and KATHRYN JONES
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Troy Lockridge hung lights on Friday on the restaurant in downtown Stephenville, Tex., where he works. In the background is the town's historic courthouse, adjacent to the newer one where Eddie Ray Routh will be tried.

item.title: Criticism, but No Penalty, for Dolan
item.description: The Knicks’ owner will not face discipline from the N.B.A. over an email in which he told a fan to start following the Nets “because the Knicks don’t want you.”
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW KEH
item.media:description: James Dolan’s note to a fan did not contain vulgar language, but contained several insults.

item.title: At the Museum of London, the City That Sherlock Holmes Knew
item.description: The show “The Man Who Never Lived and Will Never Die” examines the ways the British capital of the late 19th and early 20th centuries was entwined with Arthur Conan Doyle’s stories.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SULCAS
item.media:description: John O’Connor’s “From Pentonville Road Looking West: Evening,” in a show at the Museum of London.

item.title: Debate That Divides: Alabama, Where Same-Sex Marriage Remains Deeply Unpopular
item.description: Although support has risen across much of the country, it does not seem to have changed much in areas that are strongly opposed.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By NATE COHN
item.media:credit: Gary Cosby Jr./The Decatur Daily, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yashinari Effinger kissed Adrian Thomas as they were declared a married couple Monday in Big Spring Park in Huntsville, Ala.

item.title: Bits Blog: Twitter Reports a Surge in Government Data Requests
item.description: The report said total government requests for data rose by 40 percent, to about 2,881, compared with the company’s last report, in July.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE ISAAC
item.media:credit: Kayhan Ozer/Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey. The most government requests for Twitter users' information, according to the company’s latest report, came from Turkey.
